column1: Probably the most widely accepted theory explaining the evolution of larval stages is the need for dispersal. Sessile organisms such as barnacles and tunicates
column2: and sea-floor groups like mussels and crabs
column3: need some way to move their young into new territory
column4: since they cannot move long distances as adults. Many species have relatively long pelagic larval stages (how long a larva is in the water column). During this time
column6: and many species move through several stages of development. For example
column7: most barnacles molt through six nauplius larva stages before molting to a cipris
column8: when they look to settle. The larvae eat different food from the adults
column9: and disperse.The other consideration is the small size of the eggs. If animals lay many small eggs (and most do)
column10: then the young stages cannot live the life the adults lead. They must live a separate life until they have the size and capability to live as an adult. This is what the larvae do.
